newsitem.title: JAPAN: ADNOC offers term naphtha at $22.50 premium - trade.
newsitem.headline: ADNOC offers term naphtha at $22.50 premium - trade.

text.p: Abu Dhabi has proposed raising its naphtha price for South Korean and Japanese customers with one-year supply contracts starting July 1997, due to growing Asian naphtha demand, traders said on Thursday.
Abu Dhabi National Oil Co (ADNOC) has put forward a premium of $22.50 a tonne over the ADNOC formula, against $6.80 the previous year, traders said.
Asian customers with one-year contracts that started in January this year pay a $11.50 premium.
Most one-year Asian supply contracts with ADNOC cover cargoes lifted in the year begining January or July.
Potential buyers -- one South Korean petrochemical firm, three Japanese trading houses and one Japanese oil firm -- are due to submit their initial bids by May 21, traders said.
One of the potential buyers said they would probably place a bid in the "high teens".
Others declined to comment on bidding levels.
In the current term year ending in June, the South Korean firm has a contract for 200,000 tonnes, while the four Japanese companies are due to lift a total of 500,000 tonnes.
They are expected to lift a similar volume in the new term year, traders said.
Naphtha demand is swelling in Asia as new ethylene plants come onstream across the region, with its rapidly growing economies.
